data.name: 1_Heading
data.value: Number of appeals, cross-appeals, references, bail reviews, and judicial reviews (JRs)

data.name: 1_Info
data.value:
One notice of appeal counts as one appeal filed and one appeal disposed of, even though a number of related cases may be grouped together and heard at one hearing (example: if 10 cases are grouped together and heard together but are the subject of 10 notices of appeal, this counts as 10 appeals filed and 10 appeals disposed of). A notice of appeal containing both an appeal against conviction and against sentence, shall be counted as two appeals, but when heard together shall be counted as a single hearing.

Where an appeal was deemed abandoned or struck in the previous calendar year and restored in this calendar year, it is counted as a new appeal filed.

Cross-appeals are to be collected only if they are docket as a separate appeal.

data.name: Tip_1_1_7
data.value: FR-Previous year civil appeals, cross-appeals, references and JRs filed but still pending as of December 31st of the previous year (1.1.1) plus new civil appeals, cross-appeals, references, and JRs filed (1.1.2) minus total number of civil appeals, cross-appeals, references, and JRs disposed of, settled by mediation, abandoned or withdrawn (1.1.3 to 1.1.6) = net civil appeals, cross-appeals, references, and JRs for the year.

data.name: Lbl_2_Heading
data.value: FR-Civil and criminal case decisions

data.name: Lbl_2_1_Title
data.value: FR-Civil case decisions

data.name: Lbl_2_1_1
data.value: FR-Number of civil case decisions given at hearing

data.name: Tip_2_1_1
data.value: FR-A decision given at hearing (also referred to as Bench decision) is a decision that is rendered immediately after the hearing, the same day of the hearing or during the same sitting week. If a decision is given at the hearing but the reasons follow the pronouncement, which means that the reasons are not provided immediately after the hearing, on the same day of the hearing or on the same sitting week of the hearing, this decision should be counted as a reserved judgment.

data.name: Msg_2_1_1
data.value: FR-Number of civil appeals, cross-appeals, references, and JRs filed of civil case decisions given at hearing

data.name: Lbl_2_1_2
data.value: FR-Number of civil case reserved decisions

data.name: Tip_2_1_2
data.value: FR-A decision given after reserving is a decision that is rendered at a later date, i.e., not immediately after the hearing, not on the same day of the hearing and not during the same sitting week.

data.name: Msg_2_1_2
data.value: EN-Number of civil case reserved decisions

data.name: Lbl_2_2_Title
data.value: FR-Criminal case decisions

data.name: Lbl_2_2_1
data.value: FR-Number of criminal case decisions given at hearing

data.name: Tip_2_2_1
data.value:
FR-A decision given at hearing (also referred to as Bench decision) is a decision that is rendered immediately after the hearing, the same day of the hearing or during the same sitting week. If a decision is given at the hearing but the reasons follow the pronouncement, which means that the reasons are not provided immediately after the hearing, on the same day of the hearing or on the same sitting week of the hearing, this decision should be counted as a reserved judgment.

The decisions involving the Youth Criminal Justice Act are not to be tracked separately. They should be counted as any other criminal appeal decision.

data.name: Msg_2_2_1
data.value: FR-Number of criminal case decisions given at hearing

data.name: Lbl_2_2_1_3
data.value: FR-Number of other criminal appeals given at hearing

data.name: Tip_2_2_1_3
data.value: FR-Examples of other criminal appeals are habeas corpus, prohibition, certiorari, mental disorder reviews, etc.

data.name: Msg_2_2_1_3
data.value: FR-Number of other criminal appeals given at hearing

data.name: Lbl_2_2_2
data.value: FR-Number of criminal case decisions filed after reserving

data.name: Tip_2_2_2
data.value: FR-A decision filed after reserving is a decision that is rendered at a later date i.e. not on the same day of the hearing or during the same sitting week. If a decision is given at the hearing but the reasons follow the pronouncement i.e., they are not provided immediately after the hearing, on the same day of the hearing or during the same sitting week, this decision should be counted as a reserved judgment.

data.name: Msg_2_2_2
data.value: FR-Number of criminal case decisions filed after reserving

data.value: FR-Number of convictions/acquittals filed after reserving

data.value: FR-Number of sentences filed after reserving

data.name: Msg_2_2_2_2
data.value: FR-Number of sentences filed after reserving

data.name: Lbl_2_2_2_3
data.value: FR-Number of other criminal appeals filed after reserving

data.name: Tip_2_2_2_3
data.value: FR-Examples of criminal appeals are habeas corpus, prohibition, certiorari, mental disorder reviews.

data.name: Msg_2_2_2_3
data.value: FR-Number of other criminal appeals filed after reserving

data.name: Lbl_3_Heading
data.value: FR-Number of decisions/judgments (total)

data.name: Lbl_3_1
data.value: FR-Number of Bench decisions/judgments

data.name: Tip_3_1
data.value: FR-Bench decisions/judgments are also referred to as decisions given at hearing. A Bench decision or decision given at hearing is rendered immediately after the hearing, the same day of the hearing or during the same sitting week. The decisions involving the Youth Criminal Justice Act are not to be tracked separately. They should be counted as any other decision/judgment.

data.name: Msg_3_1
data.value: FR-Number of Bench decisions/judgments

data.name: Lbl_3_2
data.value: FR-Number of reserved decisions/judgments

data.name: Tip_3_2
data.value: FR-A reserved decision is a decision that is rendered at a later date i.e. not immediately after the hearing, not on the same day of the hearing nor during the same sitting week. The decisions involving the Youth Criminal Justice Act are not to be tracked separately. They should be counted as any other criminal appeal decision.

data.name: Msg_3_2
data.value: FR-Number of reserved decisions/judgments

data.name: Lbl_4_Heading
data.value: FR-Civil and criminal case time intervals

data.name: Tip_4_Heading
data.value:
FR-Civil and criminal case statistics are to be collected for three time intervals: 1) Notice of appeal to filing of the appellant’s factum (or the equivalent document), 2) Filing of appellant’s factum to hearing, and 3) Hearing to final decision.

For each of these time intervals, information will be gathered for three time periods: 1) Less than 6 months, 2) Between 6 to 12 months, and 3) More than 12 months.

data.name: Lbl_4_1
data.value: FR-This time interval refers to the interval from the time a notice of appeal is filed (either as of right or after a motion for leave to appeal has been granted) to the time the appellant’s factum is filed and the appeal is ready to be set down for a hearing. The appeal is considered ready to be set down for a hearing on the date at which the appellant has done everything required by the rules of court to prepare an appeal for hearing (typically the serving and filing of the appeal book, transcripts and appellant’s factum). On references, the date the Order in Council or of the originating document is received will replace the notice of appeal date.

data.name: Lbl_CivilCases
data.value: FR-Civil cases

data.name: Lbl_CriminalCases
data.value: FR-Criminal cases

data.name: Tip_CriminalCases
data.value: FR-For criminal cases, the time intervals and time periods should be reported for each of the following three categories of criminal appeals: 1) Conviction/acquittal, 2) Sentence, and 3) Other.

data.name: Lbl_4_1_1
data.value: FR-Number of civil appeals where the interval from the notice of appeal to filing of the appellant’s factum took less than 6 months

data.name: Msg_4_1_1
data.value: FR-Number of civil appeals where the interval from the notice of appeal to filing of the appellant’s factum took less than 6 months

data.value: FR-For criminal cases, the time intervals and time periods should be reported for each of the following three categories of criminal appeals: 1) Conviction/acquittal, 2) Sentence, and 3) Other.

data.name: Sec4_Heading
data.value: FR-Civil and criminal case time intervals

data.name: Sec4_Heading_Tip
data.value:
FR-Civil and criminal case statistics are to be collected for three time intervals: 1) Notice of appeal to filing of the appellant’s factum (or the equivalent document), 2) Filing of appellant’s factum to hearing, and 3) Hearing to final decision.

For each of these time intervals, information will be gathered for three time periods: 1) Less than 6 months, 2) Between 6 to 12 months, and 3) More than 12 months.

data.name: Sec4_411_Label
data.value: FR-Number of civil appeals where the interval from the notice of appeal to filing of the appellant’s factum took less than 6 months

data.name: Sec4_412_Label
data.value: FR-Number of civil appeals where the interval from the notice of appeal to filing of the appellant’s factum took between 6 to 12 months

data.name: Sec4_413_Label
data.value: FR-Number of civil appeals where the interval from the notice of appeal to filing of the appellant’s factum took more than 12 months

data.name: Sec4_414_Label
data.value: FR-Number of criminal appeals where the interval from the notice of appeal to filing of the appellant’s factum took less than 6 months for:

data.name: Sec4_415_Label
data.value: FR-Number of criminal appeals where the interval from the notice of appeal to filing of the appellant’s factum took between 6 to 12 months for:

data.name: Sec4_416_Label
data.value: FR-Number of criminal appeals where the interval from the notice of appeal to filing of the appellant’s factum took more than 12 months for:

data.name: Sec4_41_Heading
data.value: FR-Notice of appeal to filing of the appellant’s factum

data.name: Sec4_41_Tip
data.value: FR-This time interval refers to the interval from the time a notice of appeal is filed (either as of right or after a motion for leave to appeal has been granted) to the time the appellant’s factum is filed and the appeal is ready to be set down for a hearing. The appeal is considered ready to be set down for a hearing on the date at which the appellant has done everything required by the rules of court to prepare an appeal for hearing (typically the serving and filing of the appeal book, transcripts and appellant’s factum). On references, the date the Order in Council or of the originating document is received will replace the notice of appeal date.

data.name: Sec4_CivilCases
data.value: FR-Civil cases

data.name: Sec4_CriminalCases
data.value: FR-Criminal cases

data.name: Sec4_CriminalCases_Tip
data.value: FR-For criminal cases, the time intervals and time periods should be reported for each of the following three categories of criminal appeals: 1) Conviction/acquittal, 2) Sentence, and 3) Other.

data.name: Sec4_42_Heading
data.value: FR-Filing of the appellant’s factum to hearing

data.name: Sec4_42_Tip
data.value:
FR-This time interval refers to the time required from the time the appellant’s factum is filed to the time the case is heard. The time the appeal is heard is the actual day of the appeal hearing and not the scheduled date of hearing.

Where the hearing consumes more than one day, use the first day of hearing for calculating the filing of the appellant’s factum to hearing time interval and the hearing to final decision time interval.

data.name: Sec4_421_Label
data.value: FR-Number of civil appeals where the time interval from filing of the appellant’s factum to the hearing took less than 6 months

data.name: Sec4_422_Label
data.value: FR-Number of civil appeals where the time interval from filing of the appellant’s factum to the hearing took between 6 to 12 months

data.name: Sec4_423_Label
data.value: FR-Number of civil appeals where the time interval from filing of the appellant’s factum to the hearing took more than 12 months

data.name: Sec4_424_Label
data.value: FR-Number of criminal appeals where the time interval from filing of the appellant’s factum to the hearing took less than 6 months for:

data.name: Sec4_425_Label
data.value: FR-Number of criminal appeals where the time interval from filing of the appellant’s factum to the hearing took between 6 to 12 months for:

data.name: Sec4_426_Label
data.value: FR-Number of criminal appeals where the time interval from filing of the appellant’s factum to the hearing took more than 12 months for:

data.name: Sec4_43_Heading
data.value: FR-Hearing to final decision

data.name: Sec4_43_Tip
data.value: FR-This time interval refers to the time between the day of the hearing (actual day of hearing and <u>not</u> the scheduled date of hearing) and the date of the decision/judgment.

data.name: Sec4_431_Label
data.value: FR-Number of civil appeals where the time interval from the hearing to the final decision took less than 6 months

data.name: Sec4_432_Label
data.value: FR-Number of civil appeals where the time interval from the hearing to the final decision took between 6 to 12 months

data.name: Sec4_433_Label
data.value: FR-Number of civil appeals where the time interval from the hearing to the final decision took more than 12 months

data.name: Sec4_434_Label
data.value: FR-Number of criminal appeals where the time interval from the hearing to the final decision took less than 6 months for:

data.name: Sec4_435_Label

data.name: Sec5_Heading
data.value: FR-Number of in-person, virtual and hybrid hearings

data.name: Sec5_Heading_Tip
data.value: FR-The number of hearings in this section are to be collected for <u>hearings by a panel of judges only</u>.)

data.name: Sec5_51_Label_Short
data.value: FR-In-person hearings

data.name: Sec5_51_Tip
data.value: FR-Number of hearings held where all parties were present in court for the hearing. This description also includes situations where the counsel attended the hearing in-person but where the individual being represented attended remotely/virtually.

data.name: Sec5_52_Label_Short
data.value: FR-Virtual hearings

data.name: Sec5_52_Tip
data.value: FR-Number of hearings held where all parties attended the hearing remotely/virtually.

data.name: Sec5_53_Label_Short
data.value: FR-Hybrid hearings

data.name: Sec5_53_Tip
data.value: FR-Number of hearings held where one or more parties were present in court for the hearing and one or more parties attended the hearing remotely/virtually.

data.name: Sec5_54_Label
data.value: FR-Total number of hearings held in-person, virtually and in hybrid mode

data.name: Sec5_54_Tip
data.value: FR-This field is auto-populated using fields 5.1 to 5.3

data.name: Sec6_Heading
data.value: FR-Number of motions and applications

data.name: Sec6_Heading_Tip
data.value:
FR-The number of motions and applications heard in chambers (single judge), in court (panels of three or more judges) and by registrars. In some jurisdictions, motions and applications can be heard by a master or other judicial officers.

Motions and applications heard at the time of the hearing of an appeal are not to be included. Motions and applications in writing should be included. Consent orders should also be included if judicial time is required to deal with them.

With respect to applications for leave to appeal or leave to extend the time to appeal:

1. Where leave is granted, these applications should be counted as both a motion heard and as an appeal filed and subsequently disposed of by judgment or by other means. Where the practice of the court is to open a new (second) file, count the motion heard only on the first file and the appeal filed on the second file, or

2. Where only the motion or application is heard and leave is denied, these applications should be counted only as a motion heard by a motion judge or judges. However, when the entire appeal is heard and leave is denied by an appellate panel, then these applications should be counted only as an appeal disposed of by other means.

data.name: Sec6_61_Label
data.value: FR-Motions and applications heard by a single judge

data.name: Sec6_611_Label
data.value: FR-Number of motions and applications filed before a single judge

data.name: Sec6_612_Label
data.value: FR-Number of motions and applications disposed of by order of a single judge

data.name: Sec6_613_Label
data.value: FR-Number of motions and applications before a single judge that were abandoned, withdrawn or dismissed administratively

data.name: Sec6_613_Tip
data.value: FR-Examples of dismissed administratively include dismissed for want of prosecution, non-compliance with rules, applications where leave is denied, etc.

data.name: Sec6_623_Tip
data.value: FR-Examples of dismissed administratively include dismissed for want of prosecution, non-compliance with rules, applications where leave is denied, etc.

data.name: Sec6_633_Tip
data.value: FR-Examples of administrative reasons include dismissed for want of prosecution, non-compliance with rules, applications where leave is denied, etc.

data.name: Sec7_Heading
data.value: FR-Self-Represented Litigants (SRLs)

data.name: Sec7_Heading_Tip
data.value:
FR-An SRL is a person who appears in court without representation from a lawyer. The litigant is not to be considered an SRL if the court has appointed counsel to assist the litigant.

The number of appeals and the number of motions involving an SRL is only collected at the hearing. For example, if a person is represented by a lawyer at the filing stage of an appeal or motion but is not represented at the hearing, the appeal or motion is considered an SRL case.

data.name: Sec7_711_Label
data.value: FR-Number of appeals involving an SRL at the hearing of the appeal on the merits

data.name: Sec7_712_Label
data.value: FR-Number of motions and applications involving an SRL at the hearing of a motion or an application (by a single judge, a panel or the registrar)

data.name: Sec7_712_Tip
data.value: FR-Motions and applications heard at the time of the hearing of an appeal are not to be included.

data.name: Sec7_713_Label
data.value: FR-Total number of appeals, motions and applications involving an SRL at the hearing

data.name: Sec7_713_Tip
data.value: FR-This field is auto-populated using fields 7.1.1 and 7.1.2.
